New Records: Antonin Barak was sent off in the 20th minute, setting a new record for the earliest sending-off in Euro history, beating the previous record held by Eric Abidal (24 minutes against Italy at Euro 2008)
Key Match Events: Cenk Tosun scored the winning goal in injury time, securing Turkey's qualification for the knockout stages
The game ended with 18 cards shown, 16 of which were yellows and 2 were reds, setting a new record for the most cards awarded in a single game at a European Championship
The Czech Republic's bench was involved in a scuffle with Turkey players after the final whistle
Pre-Game Insights: The Czech Republic started the game well, disturbing Turkey's midfield technicians with a man-to-man pressing system
Post-Match Reflections: The referee, Istvan Kovacs, was criticized for his decisions, including the early sending-off of Antonin Barak
The game was described as the 'dirtiest game in Euros history' due to the high number of cards shown
Miscellaneous Highlights: The game started with a yellow card for Antonin Barak, who was involved in a physical challenge with Ismail Yuksek
Patrik Schick, the Czech Republic's all-time leading scorer at the Euros, was given a yellow card for dissent
Ugurcan Cakir, Turkey's backup goalkeeper, will miss their round-of-16 tie against Austria due to a yellow card
Others: The game was marked by controversy and physicality, with many players and coaches involved in scuffles and confrontations
